ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about the craft of non-fiction creative writing and how to make my own writing more substantial.
I gained insight into the foundations of writing a successful personal essay, including various specific techniques and strategies used by modern essayists.
I learned how to read essays closely and with purpose, as well as how to write good creative nonfiction.
Dissecting mostly non-fictional essays, understanding the techniques used by published writers and applying it to your own writing.

I learned how to analyze and break apart the works of nonfiction writers, and ultimately how to use the skills that we identified in my own personal writing. My writing also genuinely just got so much better after taking this course!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: readings were always very refreshing and enjoyable (mostly selections from The New Yorker or The NYT, essays that you'd want to read in your own time anyway), feedback was helpful and clear, and Pam was a great resource and super knowledgeable. I would also say that this class translated the best to Zoom. This semester, I've also taken math classes and lecture courses and this class has been the most engaging out of all of them. 
I would say one weakness was the timing of the essays; we had four essays over the course of the semester and sometimes the first draft of the next essay would be due a week after you just submitted the final draft of another essay. I wouldn't fault anyone in particular for this, as the timing of the semester was challenging for everyone, but it was definitely tough to manage as a first-year.

Strengths: the reading material was well-selected and quite engaging

Weaknesses: discussions were often quite dull, static, and uninteresting. Perhaps this was due to the online format.

Strengths: I really loved everything that we read, and I was able to apply the skills from the readings and our discussions to my own writing. I vastly improved as a writer over the course of the semester. Professor Newton is also really engaging, and I always enjoyed seminars. 
Weaknesses: Other than workshops, we didn't really talk about our own essays in class, so it was sometimes difficult to get started on an essay, both choosing a topic and writing a draft.

Strengths: The readings was always super interesting, to the point where they never really felt like homework. The essays were also fun to write because they were personal and about topics that I genuinely cared about. Also, submitting a draft before the final essay was something I appreciated, because it gave the opportunity for feedback and improvement. Weaknesses: Honestly not many, but I would say that sometimes class felt a little repetitive because you essentially do the same thing every day, although every class was still interesting and engaging.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that synchronous instruction really helped and worked to keep students engaged. Once or twice we had discussion boards to jumpstart the in-class discussion, and I don't think I got much out of those boards.
Ideally, the class discussion format could be improved to allow for more engagement or interaction with other students

I could imagine that workshops and other discussions (equivalent to breakout rooms) would be more dynamic in person, but this class worked really well remotely. The class discussions were effective, and even reading everything off of my computer didn't hinder my experience reading the essays.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: 100% would recommend! It was both an intellectual challenge and really fun to take, especially since the materials are meant to be entertaining.
I would recommend this course to those students who already consider themselves strong writers and have a vested interest in the creative nonfiction genre in particular.

I would absolutely recommend this class. Even as someone who never really enjoyed English classes, this was my favorite course that I took this semester. I learned a lot about myself both as a student and as a person through the wide variety of texts that we read, and everything was super digestible and engaging.

Yes! English 120 is a great way to get your writing requirement: its fun, engaging, and will definitely help your writing skills improve. I would definitely recommend taking it with Pam, she gave such amazing, detailed feedback on all of our papers and was just super caring towards her students and their success.
